description:
Trematosphaeria pertusa is a species of fungus that belongs to the phylum Ascomycota, class Dothideomycetes, and order Pleosporales. It is a saprobic fungus, meaning it derives its nutrients from decaying organic matter.

T. pertusa is typically found growing on the bark of various tree species, particularly in temperate and subtropical regions. Its fruiting bodies, known as ascomata, are small, dark-colored, and flask-shaped structures that emerge from the surface of the bark. These ascomata produce spore-bearing structures called asci, which contain ascospores that are released and dispersed by wind or water.

The ascospores of T. pertusa are typically dark-colored, septate (divided by internal walls), and have a distinctive, perforated or "punctured" appearance, which is the source of the species' name "pertusa" (meaning "perforated" in Latin).

T. pertusa plays a role in the decomposition of dead plant material, contributing to the cycling of nutrients in forest ecosystems. It is considered a common and widespread species, but its precise ecological functions and interactions with other organisms are still not fully understood.
